Stop Worrying about Climate Change

And start worrying about the overall poisoning of the planet, and of ourselves.

Daniel Goldman
Feb 16

Probably one of the most politically charged terms in science is “climate change.” There’s a lot of science and pseudoscience involved. There’s a lot of sensationalism too. But that sensationalism has resulted in a lot of people completely rejecting the notion of human caused climate change. And that’s why we need to focus on the bigger issue.

We’re poisoning the planet. It’s hard to argue otherwise. Even ignoring carbon dioxide, the burning of fossil fuels releases mercury, surfer, and even radioactive material into the atmosphere. Those waste products make their way into the biosphere, and into our own bodies.

And I used to hear about things like acid rain, smog, mercury pollution, and so on, all the time. But these days, all I hear is climate change, climate change, climate change. Yes; climate change is a problem, and we need to deal with it. But it’s far from the only ecological issue or health issue that we’re creating by polluting.

And while a lot of people argue over the extent of climate change and the amount of risk it poses, I think it’s harder to argue against the immediate effects that we’re seeing from the aforementioned toxication of the environment.

Smog and Asthma

Asthma and COPD can be exacerbated by smog. And we can even see that in at least some regions with seasonal smog show, there’s a marked increase in hospital visits for both asthma and COPD (Pothirat et al.).

Mercury

I love sushi. And so the issue of mercury in seafood is a major concern for me. But it’s not just saltwater fish that we need to worry about. According to the USGS, “48 out of 50 States have at least one commonly consumed fish species that exceeds the 0.3 ppm USEPA criterion for the protection of people who eat average amounts of fish.” Furthermore, the primary form of mercury found in these fish is methylmercury, which is generally considered a more toxic form than ethylmercury.

Mining

Mining’s a problem for just about all forms of energy. Even solar power has a mining problem, because the raw materials for the solar panels need to be mined. Additionally, solar and wind require a lot of energy storage, which often comes in the form of Lithium based cells. Electric cars suffer the same issue. Wired has a good article on the spiraling environmental cost of lithium batteries.

Trends

So first off, something that’s interesting is that there seems to be some rather apparent cyclical search habits, especially when it comes to acid rain. But you can also see that searches for acid rain have been on the decline, while searches for climate change and smog have been increasing. Even still, searches for climate change blow the other two out of the water.

Cost

Healthcare costs aren’t always addressed when it comes to discussions of prices of various fuels. And the indirect costs of fossil fuels can be very high. The direct healthcare costs of asthma and COPD results in billions of dollars in healthcare expenditures every year. But asthma is also one of the leading reasons why people miss work. (AAFA)

Changing Envirocomm

I don’t have exact numbers off the top of my head, but that’s not the real point. The point is that our pollution is costing us a lot of money, and that’s money that could be spent on growth instead. So even if we completely ignored climate change, there health and economic costs of our current way of doing things is just too much to ignore.

But we are ignoring it. Even many environmentalists are ignoring it. Politicians are definitely ignoring it. The entire Green New Deal is basically just climate change sensationalism. It ignores all the other ways in which we’re poisoning the planet. It ignores mercury, plastics, mining, and so much more. And that needs to be changed. Environmental communication needs to address all of these issues.
